title: Density graph of mass as a function of volume

content.question: Students have a set of blocks of various sizes all made of Material <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>. They also have a similar set of blocks of various sizes, which are made of Material <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>. The students measure the mass and volume of all the blocks and create the graph of the data shown. Which of the following conclusions can be made from the graph?

choices.label: Material <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is more dense than Material <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.
Material <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> is more dense than Material <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>.
Materials <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> have the same density.
The density of each block increases with increasing volume.

content.answer: Material <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is more dense than Material <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
